pageData.text: In this investigation, you will examine the muscular system through the dissection of a preserved adult rat. Over the course of two activities, the <button class='glossary-text'>superficial</button> and deeper musculature will be observed. Selected muscles will be identified by location, appearance, <button class='glossary-text'>origin</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>insertion</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>action</button>. It is best to perform this investigation following a survey of the skeleton, including individual bones and their surface features.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 45 minutes
Activity 1: Superficial Musculature - 90 minutes
Activity 2: Deep Musculature - 90 minutes
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 45 minutes
Activity 1: Superficial Musculature - 90 minutes
Activity 2: Deep Musculature - 90 minutes

Use correct anatomical terminology to describe features and orientations.

pageData.text: Every year many different weightlifting competitions take place around the world. There are events for every age group, and traditionally these events are further separated by gender. Men and women usually do not compete against each other to give the athletes a level playing field – but is one gender stronger than the other?

The record for the most weight lifted was set in 1957 by Paul Anderson at 2,844 kg (6,270 lbs). Currently, one of the strongest professional male weightlifters is Andrey Malanichev. Malanichev weighs 342 pounds and can squat a little over three times his body weight. His record squat is 485 kg (1,069 lbs), bench press is 260 kg (570 lbs), and deadlift is 405 kg (893 lbs).

Becca Swanson is currently the only woman to squat more than 800 pounds. Her best lift for the squat is 388 kg (854 lbs), bench press is 273 kg (601 lbs), and deadlift is 310 kg (683 lbs). In 2006, Becca Swanson weighed 89.36 kg (197 lbs) and squatted 365 kg (804.7 lbs), which was four times her body weight.
Who are stronger – men or women?

pageData.desc: A man lifting weights on a bar bell.
pageData.altText: A man lifting weights on a bar bell.

pageData.subTitle: Introduction to the Skeletal Muscles
pageData.text: There are about 640 skeletal muscles in the human body. Each skeletal muscle is an organ composed of skeletal (or voluntary) muscle cells (known as <button class='glossary-text'>fibers</button> for their long, slender shape); connective tissue, including vascular (blood) tissue; and nervous tissue, which receives input from the central nervous system to stimulate muscle contraction. The muscular system works together with the skeletal system to generate body movements.

Each skeletal muscle can be described in terms of its , , and . The origin is defined as the bone that the muscle is attached to that has the greater mass and stability during contraction. It is typically the more (closer to the body’s midline or center) point of attachment. The insertion is the bone or other point of attachment (such as a tendon or other connective tissue) that tends to move the greatest distance when the muscle contracts. The muscle insertion is typically less massive and more (farther from the body’s midline or center) than the origin. The is the movement that results when the muscle contracts. As you dissect and examine the muscular system of an adult rat, you will notice that many of the names of individual muscles describe their particular origin, insertion, and/or action.

Figure 1 illustrates two skeletal muscles, the biceps and triceps of the human arm, together with their <button class='glossary-text'>origins</button> and insertions. Note the bones of the shoulder and arm: the scapula (also known as the shoulder blade), the humerus of the upper arm, and the radius and ulna of the forearm. The biceps muscle of the upper arm is attached by two origins (and therefore has two heads) to the scapula. The biceps runs the length of the humerus and is attached to the radius at its <button class='glossary-text'>insertion</button>. The triceps muscle of the upper arm is attached by three origins (and therefore has three heads), one to the scapula and two to the humerus. In Figure 1, only two of the origins are visible. The third triceps origin is indicated but not visible. The triceps runs the length of the humerus on the underside of the upper arm and attaches to the ulna at its insertion.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Origins and insertions of the biceps and triceps muscles of the human upper arm

pageData.question: The_________is defined as the bone that the muscle is attached to that has the greater mass and stability during contraction and it is typically the more proximal.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The origin is the end of a muscle that is more proximal to the center of the body. The insertion is usually distal, or further away from the center of the body.

options.text: A muscle that works to extend or straighten a body part.
A muscle that bends and flexes.
A muscle that can work involuntarily.
A muscle can work on its own.
A muscle that can also be a flexor muscle.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Extensors extend or straighten a body part. They are antagonists to muscles called flexors, and vice versa.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: There are about 640 skeletal muscles in the human body. Each skeletal muscle can be described in terms of its origin, insertion, and action. A muscle has two ends that each attach to bone, the muscle's origin, and the muscle's insertion. During muscular contraction, such as the contraction of the biceps, the origin of the muscle does not move; the arm bends at the elbow joint as the insertion on the forearm is pulled toward the origin on the shoulder blade. The biceps muscle is called a flexor because it flexes, or bends, the elbow joint. The triceps muscle works in opposition to the biceps. When the triceps contract, the insertion is pulled away from the origin, causing the arm to straighten, or extend, at the elbow. The triceps is therefore an extensor muscle.

img.alt: Figure 1: Origins and insertions of the biceps and triceps muscles of the human upper arm

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: There are about 640 skeletal muscles in the human body. Each skeletal muscle can be described in terms of its origin, insertion, and action. A muscle has two ends that each attach to bone, the muscle's origin, and the muscle's insertion. During muscular contraction, such as the contraction of the biceps, the origin of the muscle does not move; the arm bends at the elbow joint as the insertion on the forearm is pulled toward the origin on the shoulder blade. The biceps muscle is called a flexor because it flexes, or bends, the elbow joint. The triceps muscle works in opposition to the biceps. When the triceps contract, the insertion is pulled away from the origin, causing the arm to straighten, or extend, at the elbow. The triceps is therefore an extensor muscle.

img.alt: Figure 1: Origins and insertions of the biceps and triceps muscles of the human upper arm

pageData.text: When a skeletal muscle contracts, it becomes shorter, and its <button class='glossary-text'>insertion</button> is pulled toward its stationary <button class='glossary-text'>origin</button>, causing bones to move at a joint. It is important to note that muscles act by exerting a pulling force, never a pushing force. Muscles are shorter and thicker when contracted than when they are relaxed. When the biceps contracts, the arm bends at the elbow joint as the insertion on the forearm is pulled toward the origin on the shoulder blade. The biceps muscle is called a <button class='glossary-text'>flexor</button> because it flexes, or bends, the elbow joint. The triceps muscle works in opposition to the biceps. When the triceps contracts, the insertion is pulled away from the origin, causing the arm to straighten, or extend, at the elbow. Therefore, the triceps is an <button class='glossary-text'>extensor</button> muscle.

The biceps and triceps flank the upper arm and work as an <button class='glossary-text'>antagonistic muscle pair</button> across the elbow joint. In other words, when one contracts (the <button class='glossary-text'>agonist</button> or <button class='glossary-text'>prime mover</button>), the contraction is modulated by the opposing simultaneous <button class='glossary-text'>action</button> of the other (the <button class='glossary-text'>antagonist</button>). However, antagonists are not usually active when the agonist is contracting. Flexors (like the biceps) are antagonists of extensors (like the triceps), and vice versa. Movement produced by the contraction of the biceps muscle and the “relaxation” of the triceps can be reversed by the contraction of the triceps muscle and the “relaxation” of the biceps. Other movable bones of the skeleton are also flanked by antagonistic skeletal muscle pairs, or muscle groups, to control body movements across joints.

<button class='glossary-text'>Synergists</button> are muscles that work together and facilitate movements brought about by agonists at movable joints. Whereas the agonist provides most of the force for a particular movement, synergists may stabilize the joint (thus preventing undesirable movement) or even modify the movement. For example, the biceps in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 1</button> is a flexor of the forearm at the elbow joint. The brachialis, lying <button class='glossary-text'>deep</button> to the biceps, is a synergist.

pageData.subTitle: Terminology
pageData.text: Anatomists and health care providers use specific terminology to ensure precise communication. Directional anatomical terms (Figure 2, <button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button>) describe the relative positions of body structures. Learning these terms is an essential part of the study of anatomy and physiology. Bear in mind that all the terms in Table 1 refer to the body in the <button class='glossary-text'>standard anatomical position</button>: upright, arms at the sides, with palms forward. When referring to anatomical structures, always refer to the right or left side of the specimen or subject, not your own.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Illustration showing where the midsagittal, frontal, and transverse planes divide a quadruped (cat) and a biped (human)

tableData.text: Toward the head end of the biped body, or the upper part of a structure; above
Away from the head end of the biped body, or toward the lower part of a structure; below
Toward the front of the body; synonymous with cranial; synonymous with ventral in describing the biped body other than the head
Toward the back of the body; synonymous with caudal; synonymous with dorsal in describing the biped body other than the head
Away from the midline of the body; to the side
Near or toward the point of reference
Away from the point of reference, which is usually the attachment point
Toward the back of the body; synonymous with superior in quadrupeds, or in bipeds when referring to the head; synonymous with posterior in describing the biped body other than the head
Toward the belly or abdomen of the body; synonymous with inferior in quadrupeds, or in bipeds when referring to the head; synonymous with anterior in describing the biped body other than the head
Toward the head; synonymous with superior in bipeds
Toward the tail; synonymous with inferior in bipeds
Toward or along the surface of the body or a structure; external
Below the surface of the body or a structure; internal
Divides the body into equal left and right halves; often referred to as the midline or median plane
Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross sections
Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

pageData.question: Which of the following terms are synonymous with “anterior”?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Anterior means toward the front of the body and is synonymous with cranial (toward the head) and ventral (when describing the biped body other than the head).

pageData.question: Which of the frogs in this diagram is in a ventral position? Click the image to enlarge.

imageData.altText: Five photographs of the frog Rhombophryne ellae labeled A through E. Figure A is of a sitting frog facing to the right. Figure B is of a frog lying on its stomach. Figure C is of a frog lying on its back. Figure D is of a frog from behind. Figure E is of a sitting frog facing to the left.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The frogs in the diagram are in the following positions: a. dorsolateral view facing right; b. dorsal view; c. ventral view; d. posterior view; e. dorsolateral view facing left.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Review anatomical directions using the diagram.

img.alt: Two human body diagrams labeled with directional terms, the first a lateral view, and the second a ventral view. Superior is toward the head, and inferior is toward the feet, of each diagram. On the lateral view, a cranial-distal arrow runs vertically along the spine, with cranial toward the head, and caudal toward the tail bone. A posterior-anterior arrow runs horizontally through the back and chest, with posterior, or dorsal, toward the back, and anterior, or ventral, toward the abdomen. On the anterior view, a proximal-distal arrow runs the length of the body's right arm, with proximal toward the shoulder, and distal toward the hand. A lateral-medial arrow starts at the navel pointing horizontally away from the body, with medial at the navel, and lateral toward the body's side. Right is on the left side, and left is on the right side, of the ventral view.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Review anatomical directions using the diagram.

img.alt: Two human body diagrams labeled with directional terms, the first a lateral view, and the second a ventral view. Superior is toward the head, and inferior is toward the feet, of each diagram. On the lateral view, a cranial-distal arrow runs vertically along the spine, with cranial toward the head, and caudal toward the tail bone. A posterior-anterior arrow runs horizontally through the back and chest, with posterior, or dorsal, toward the back, and anterior, or ventral, toward the abdomen. On the anterior view, a proximal-distal arrow runs the length of the body's right arm, with proximal toward the shoulder, and distal toward the hand. A lateral-medial arrow starts at the navel pointing horizontally away from the body, with medial at the navel, and lateral toward the body's side. Right is on the left side, and left is on the right side, of the ventral view.

pageData.text: In this investigation, you will encounter muscle that cause movement around joints. The most common are listed in Table 2.

title: Table 2.
Common Muscle Actions Around Movable Joints

tableData.text: Movement of two adjacent parts toward one another, decreasing the angle between the proximal and distal parts
Movement of two adjacent parts away from one another, increasing the angle between the proximal and distal parts
Movement of a body part away from the midline (of the body as a whole or a specific region of the body)
Movement of a body part toward the midline (of the body as a whole or a specific region of the body, such as a limb)
Movement of a body part around its own axis
Inward rotation of the forearm and palm, or sole of foot
Outward rotation of the forearm and palm, or sole of foot
Movement in superior (upper) direction; for example, bringing the lower jaw (mandible) toward the upper (maxilla)
Movement in an inferior (downward) direction; for example, movement of the lower jaw (mandible) away from the upper (maxilla)

pageData.question: Which of the following movements is an example of adduction?

options.text: moving a hand toward the stomach
moving a hand to reach for something

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The movement of limbs and other body parts toward the middle of the body is called adduction.

pageData.question: Raising your arms above your shoulders is an example of which type of movement?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Abduction is the movement of the limbs away from the body.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The movements of limbs and other body parts toward or away from the center line of the body are referred to as adduction and abduction, respectively. Rotation, or circumduction, is the movement of a body around its own axis.

img.alt: A man in the anatomical position demonstrating abduction, adduction, and circumduction of his arms.

pageData.text: The following terms in <button class='resource-text'>Table 3</button> are commonly used to name and describe muscles as well as the movements for which they are responsible. As you work through the two activities in this investigation, you will use the anatomical terminology described above, as well as these and similar descriptors, to identify a range of <button class='glossary-text'>superficial</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>deep</button> muscles.

tableData.text:
Temporalis—lies over the temporal bone of the cranium
Tibialis anterior—anterior to the tibia
Supra—above
Infra—below

Adductor—responsible for adduction at a joint
Extensor—responsible for extension at a joint
Rotator—responsible for rotation at a joint
Pronator—responsible for pronation at a joint
Sternomastoid—origin on sternum/insertion on mastoid process (of temporal bone)

Rectus—fibers run parallel to long axis of muscle
Transverse—fibers run perpendicular to long axis
Oblique—fibers run oblique (slantwise) to long axis

pageData.question: Where would you find a temporalis muscle?

options.text: over the temporal bone of the cranium
to either side of the membranous viscerocranium

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The temporalis muscle lies over the temporal bone of the cranium, which is positioned over the temporal lobe.

pageData.question: In what direction do rectus fibers run?

options.text: Rectus fibers run parallel to the long axis of muscle.
Rectus fibers run perpendicular to the long axis.
Rectus fibers run oblique (slantwise) to the long axis.
Rectus fibers run perpendicular to the short axis.
Rectus fibers run infra to the short axis.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Rectus fibers run parallel to the long axis of muscle. Transverse fibers run perpendicular to long axis. Oblique fibers run oblique (slantwise) to the long axis of the

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: There is a set of terms commonly used to name and describe muscles and the movements for which they are responsible. Anatomical terminology and descriptors that indicate size, shape, or location are used to identify a range of superficial and deep muscles. The temporalis muscle, for example, is a thin, fan-shaped muscle situated over a thick bone that forms part of the side and base of the skull.

tableData.text:
Temporalis—lies over the temporal bone of the cranium

Supra—above
Infra—below

Adductor—responsible for adduction at a joint
Extensor—responsible for extension at a joint
Rotator—responsible for rotation at a joint
Pronator—responsible for pronation at a joint
Sternomastoid—origin on sternum/insertion on mastoid process (of temporal bone)

Rectus—fibers run parallel to long axis of muscle
Transverse—fibers run perpendicular to long axis
Oblique—fibers run oblique (slantwise) to long axis

pageData.desc:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation.  You will start by setting up the work area and your dissection tools. You will also remove the skin, fat and fascia from the specimen.
In Activity 1, you will need to locate and identify the superficial musculature of the head, neck and torso. Then locate and identify the superficial musculature of the forelimbs. Next, locate and identify the superficial musculature of the hindlimbs.
In Activity 2, you will need to locate and identify the deep musculature of the head, neck, and torso. Next locate and identify the deep musculature of the forelimbs. Then, locate and identify the deep musculature of the hindlimbs.
pageData.altText:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation.  You will start by setting up the work area and your dissection tools. You will also remove the skin, fat and fascia from the specimen.
In Activity 1, you will need to locate and identify the superficial musculature of the head, neck and torso. Then locate and identify the superficial musculature of the forelimbs. Next, locate and identify the superficial musculature of the hindlimbs.
In Activity 2, you will need to locate and identify the deep musculature of the head, neck, and torso. Next locate and identify the deep musculature of the forelimbs. Then, locate and identify the deep musculature of the hindlimbs.

text: Tap water
Paper towels
70% isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) or other non-bleach disinfectant
Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photos

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Muscular System Dissection investigation (item number 580511) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company. Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
This investigation requires safety goggles, disposable gloves, and a lab apron.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Follow the instructions for this activity closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including using appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE). Safety goggles, gloves, and lab aprons must be worn when dissecting. Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing the dissection. Use proper hygiene practices before, during, and after the lab, including washing your hands before and after performing the dissection. Review pertinent portions of any Safety Data Sheets before beginning the activity.
Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Dissections require special attention to safety. Please follow these additional precautions:

text: Clean the counter or work space thoroughly before and after the dissection, using isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant).

pageData.text: Isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) is flammable. Keep away from open flame if using alcohol as a disinfectant.
pageData.desc: flammable symbol
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

text: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the dissection.
Only perform the dissection on the dissecting tray. This will contain both the specimen and any excess fluids.
Spread the absorbent pad blue-side down underneath the tray to capture any spilled fluid.
Scalpels require special handling and disposal. You will not use the scalpel during this investigation.

pageData.subTitle: Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>
pageData.text: Independent, certified laboratory analyses of specimens fixed in Carolina’s Perfect Solution® have found that it is nontoxic and does not give off dangerous fumes. This means that, for safety purposes, the use of Carolina’s Perfect Solution® specimens does not require specialized ventilation. Carolina does recommend performing the dissection in a well-ventilated room with some active ventilation when working with any preserved specimens. For a home setting, this may include opening windows and turning on a ceiling fan. The safe nature of Carolina’s Perfect Solution® also means that in most localities there are no mandated disposal requirements.

pageData.subTitle: Storage of Specimens
pageData.text: If it is necessary to store the specimen between work periods, you should place it in the self-locking storage bag with as much of the original solution as possible. Establishing an airtight seal is the best way to retain specimen integrity and prevent the specimen from drying out. First, squeeze as much air out of the specimen bag as possible before securing the seal with tape or a binder clip. After sealing the bag, the specimen can be stored in a larger, airtight box or bag at room temperature.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following scenarios describes inappropriate handling of a scalpel?

options.text: Dorothy uses a scalpel to open packaging containing lab kit materials.
Jane uses a new scalpel after her old scalpel blade becomes nicked.
Yvette holds the specimen superior to the scalpel’s movement during an incision
Taylor makes sure the scalpel blade is sharp before starting the dissection.
Natalie makes incisions with the scalpel using a downward motion.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes a proper workstation set-up for this investigation?

options.text: The foam tray and tools are placed on top of the absorbent pad.
The absorbent pad and tools are placed on top of the foam tray.
The foam tray and tools are placed on top of a disinfected work surface.
The specimen is placed on a disinfected work surface alongside the tools.
The tools are placed in the disinfected foam tray.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes how to distinguish between the origin and insertion points of attachment of a particular muscle during contraction?

options.text: The origin is more stable; the insertion tends to move the greatest distance.
The origin tends to move the greatest distance; the insertion rotates 90 degrees.
The origin rotates 180 degrees; the insertion is more stable.
The origin tends to move the greatest distance; the insertion is more stable.
The origin moves farther during extension; the insertion moves farther during flexion.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the relationship between an antagonist muscle and an agonist muscle in an antagonistic muscle pair?

options.text: Contraction of the antagonist opposes the movement caused by the agonist.
Contraction of the antagonist occurs simultaneously with contraction of the agonist.
Contraction of the antagonist inhibits the movement caused by the agonist.
Contraction of the antagonist relaxes the agonist.
Contraction of the antagonist causes contraction of the agonist.

assestmentData.question: Which anatomical term means toward the right or left side?
Which of the following anatomical term means away from the point of reference (usually the attachment point)?
Which of the following muscle actions around a movable joint is characterized by the movement of a body part away from the midline, either of the body as a whole or a specific region of the body?
Which of the following terms for naming muscles means the fibers run parallel to the long axis of the muscle?
Which of the following best defines a quadriceps muscle?

options.text: a muscle with four possible movements
a muscle with four types of tissue

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes how to prepare your specimen for the activities in this investigation?

options.text: Remove the skin, fat and fascia from the specimen.
Rinse and air dry the specimen to remove excess preservation fluid.
Remove the tail from the specimen using dissection scissors.
Secure the specimen to the tray using T-pins.
No preparation is required to view the musculature of the specimen.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through each activity before beginning work.
Print out the dissection procedure to avoid getting fluid from the specimen on your computer or mobile device.
Print out the Rat Skeleton (<button class='resource-text'>Figure 14</button>) as a reference for the location of many skeletal features.

Clean the work area. Put on your PPE—safety goggles, gloves, and lab apron—and keep them on during the dissection activity and cleanup. Change gloves when handling a computer, phone, camera, or other items during the dissection to prevent contamination. Alternatively, keep your camera or mobile device in a sealed plastic bag to prevent contamination.
Lay the pad on the work area with the white, absorbent side facing up.
Lay the scissors, forceps, and blunt probe on the pad.
Place the dissecting tray in the middle of the pad to absorb any fluid that might spill onto the work area.
Before examining the musculature of therat you must remove the skin, along with fat and fascia (a membranous connective tissue with a consistency much like very strong cobwebs).

text: Place the specimen <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal</button> side down, <button class='glossary-text'>ventral</button> side up in the dissecting tray.

Use the forceps to lift the skin of the belly at the midline, and then use the scissors to cut through the lifted piece of skin. Now that an opening has been created, continue to cut cranially through the skin, taking care not to damage the underlying muscle. Using Figure 3 as a guide, cut the skin from the initial incision to the base of the chin,and then from the initial incision caudally to just <button class='glossary-text'>cranial</button> to the anal region. Likewise, cut through the skin of the limbs as shown in Figure 3. View the video:

pageData.desc: Locations for the incisions for skin removal on a rat
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Locations for the incisions for skin removal on a rat

text: After the incisions have been made, use a blunt probe to separate the skin from the fascia and muscle, working from the ventral side to the dorsal side of the body. Continue until the skin is completely separated from the body of the specimen.

pageData.text:
Notes:
  • To facilitate the removal of the skin, itis a good practice to use a blunt probe to gently separate the skin from the underlying muscle and fascia before cutting through the skin with scissors.
  • As you move up the sides of the rat towards the axillary (armpit) regions, you will encounter a large, flat muscle (the cutaneous trunci) that must be cut through the middle with the scissors in order to detach the skin. Be very careful not to cut too deeply, or you may damage deeper muscles.

text: Use the forceps to gently remove the salivary glands from the neck region (see Figure 4a and 4b).

pageData.desc: Neck region of a rat before removal of salivary glands
pageData.altText: Figure 4a: Neck region of a rat before removal of salivary glands

pageData.desc: Neck region of a rat after removal of these glands
pageData.altText: Figure 4b: Neck region of a rat after removal of these glands

text: Use the forceps to gently pick away any remaining large regions of fascia and/or fat.
The skin may be wrapped in an opaque bag and discarded in the household trash, along with the salivary glands and any remnants of fascia and fat.

Rinse the rat under running tap water for several seconds, just long enough to remove loose bits of fur. Pat the specimen dry with paper towels, wipe any loose hairs from the dissecting tray, and discard the paper towels in the household trash. Your specimen should look like the one in Figure 5a and 5b on the next page. You should refer to Figure 5a and 5b frequently during Activity 1.

pageData.desc: Ventral view of a rat with skin removed; the superficial muscles are labeled.
pageData.altText: Figure 5a: Ventral view of a rat with skin removed; the superficial muscles are labeled.

pageData.desc: Dorsal view of a rat with skin removed; the superficial muscles are labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 5b: Dorsal view of a rat with skin removed; the superficial muscles are labeled

pageData.text: In Activity 1, you will examine the musculature of a preserved rat. You will examine the head, neck and torso regions, then the forelimbs and hindlimbs. Be sure to identify and photograph all the muscles required by your instructor for Activity 1 before proceeding to Activity 2.

typeBefore.text: Take photos of all the muscles listed in this activity, which appear in bold throughout the procedure. You may group multiple muscles into the same photograph. Your kit includes T-pins, which may be used to secure the legs of the specimen while examining the musculature, or to indicate muscles of interest in your photographs.
For best practices in specimen photography, view the following video:
Please follow any additional directions provided by your instructor pertaining to the photography and/or identification of specific structures.

pageData.text: Turn the specimen <button class='glossary-text'>ventral</button> side up, <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal</button> side down, and begin your examination ofthe <button class='glossary-text'>superficial</button> musculature of the head, neck,and torso, using <button class='resource-text'>Figures 5a, 5b</button>, 6a and 6b for reference. Although you may use your blunt probe to gently coax adjacent muscles apart from one another, do not cut through any muscles during the remainder Activity 1.

pageData.desc: Ventral view of the superficial musculature of the neck and upper thoracic regions, with labels
pageData.altText: Figure 6a: Ventral view of the superficial musculature of the neck and upper thoracic regions, with labels

pageData.desc: Lateral view of the superficial musculature of the neck and upper thoracic regions, with labels
pageData.altText: Figure 6b: Lateral view of the superficial musculature of the neck and upper thoracic regions, with labels

pageData.text: Locate the masseter, the large muscle of the cheek, on each side of the rat’s face.This muscle has its on the zygomatic process of the face, and its on the mandible. Its primary function is to elevate the mandible and close the mouth, although it also helps move the mandible laterally when the rat gnaws. Turn the rat onto its sides to more closely examine the masseter.

Restore the specimen to its original, ventral side up position. Between the masseters you should see a muscle with origins on the mastoid process of the temporal bone just behind the ears, and the occipital bone at the rear of the cranium, called the digastric. It inserts on the ventral side of the mandible (the chin), and is the main muscle responsible for depressing the mandible, thereby opening the mouth. Notice that the digastric is divided into a belly and a belly by a centrally located tendon.

The sternohyoid is positioned immediately caudal to the central tendon of the digastric. It originates on the cartilage of the first rib (the first costal cartilage), and inserts on the hyoid bone, which is located in the ventral neck. When this muscle contracts, the tongue, which is anchored to the hyoid, extends.
The sternomastoid, which originates on the sternum and inserts on the mastoid process, is easily located, as it lies just to the sternohyoid. Contraction of the sternomastoid turns the head.

The cleidocervicalis runs lateral and slightly dorsal to the sternomastoid. Its origins are on the back of the skull and the midline of the dorsal neck region, and its insertion is on the clavicle (collarbone). This muscle serves to move the clavicle as well as the scapula (shoulder blade) forward.

The cleidobrachialis lies lateral to the cleidocervicalis. It is a roughly triangular muscle with its origin on the clavicle and insertion on the humerus. (You may turn the specimen onto its side to view the entire muscle.) The main of the cleidobrachialis is to move the forelimb forward.

Turn the specimen dorsal side up. Locate the temporalis, just caudal to the eye on the lateral aspect of the head. You may need to roll the specimen onto its side to see the entire muscle. This muscle is responsible for elevating the mandible and flexing the head. Its origin is on the temporal fossa (a large, flattened area on the lateral aspect of the cranium); its insertion is on the mandible.

Turn the specimen ventral side up. Locate the omotransversarius, which runs laterally down the length of the neck. You may need to turn the specimen onto its side to get a clear view of the entire muscle. This muscle has its origin on the first cervical vertebra, known as the atlas, and its insertion on the dorsal side of the scapula. Contraction of the omotransversarius moves the scapula cranially.

Turn the specimen dorsal side up. Locatethe cervical trapezius, a wide muscle that originates at the fourth thoracic vertebra (T4) and inserts on the scapula. It serves to adduct and also stabilize the scapula.
The spinodeltoid has its origin on the spine of the scapula and inserts on the humerus at a feature called the deltoid ridge. It is an abductor and of the humerus.
The thoracic trapezius is a wide muscle that originates at the midline of the dorsal thoracic region and inserts on the spine of the scapula. Contraction causes the scapula to undergo dorsal .
The latissimus dorsi is a wide, flat muscle that originates along the fascia of the dorsal thoracic region and inserts on the portion of the humerus. It is an of the humerus.
The serratus ventralis is so named because of its serrated or ridged appearance. It originates on the ribs and inserts on the dorsal side of the scapula, which it depresses.

Turn the specimen ventral side up. Look for the large, flat, triangular region running from the shoulders to the abdomen. The two muscles found here are the pectoralis superficialis and the pectoralis profundus, both of which originate on the sternum, insert on the portion of the humerus, and adduct the humerus. The pectoralis profundus can only be viewed at the caudal edge of the “triangular region” without cutting through the pectoralis superficialis. (Do not cut through any muscles at this time.)

The external oblique is the broad, thin superficial muscle of the abdomen. It has its origin on the ribs and in the fascia of the dorsal thoracolumbar region, and its insertion is visible as the linea alba, the thin, fibrous structure that runs straight down the ventral midline of the abdomen. Contraction of the external oblique compresses the abdomen and flexes the trunk.
Continue your examination of the superficial musculature by looking at the forelimb of the specimen, using <button class='resource-text'>Figures 5a, 5b</button>, 7a and 7b for reference.

pageData.altText: Figure 7a: Ventral view of the superficial musculature of the forelimb, with labels
Figure 7b: Dorsal view of the superficial musculature of the forelimb, with labels.

pageData.text: Turn the specimen ventral side down, dorsal side up, extend the forelimb, and look along its cranial region for the brachialis. This muscle has its origin on the dorsal aspect of the humerus and its insertion on the medial aspect of the ulna. Its contraction flexes the forelimb.

Much of the forelimb is occupied by the large triceps brachii. This forelimb extensor may appear to be two distinct muscles, but it is actually one muscle with a medially situated long head and a lateral head. The long head has its origin on the scapula, while the lateral head originates on the lateral aspect of the humerus. The triceps brachii inserts on the olecranon process of the ulna.

Note: Superficial to the most medial area of the triceps is a very thin muscle called the tensor fasciae antebrachii, which originates on the border of the latissimus dorsi and inserts on the fascia of the forelimb. It is often torn during the process of skinning the specimen. However, if the muscle is still present, you may bisect it (cut it in half) using the scissors. Lift the muscle away from the underlying triceps to avoid damage during the bisection. Then reflect (push back) the two severed ends of the muscle to reveal the triceps underneath.

The and portion of the forelimb features a group of muscles that extend the wrist (carpus), paw (manus), and toes (digits). For instance, the extensor carpi radialis extends the manus. It originates on the lateral epicondyle of the humerus and inserts on metacarpal III.

of the carpus is enacted by the flexor carpi ulnaris. This muscle of the superficial and lateral distal forelimb has origins on the medial epicondyle of the humerus and the olecranon process of the ulna, and inserts on the accessory carpal. (You may need to turn the forelimb slightly to see the entire muscle.)

Turn the specimen ventral side up and look at the medial superficial muscles of the forelimb. The biceps brachii lies just medial to the brachialis. It has two heads, both on the scapula. The long head originates on the border of the glenoid fossa, and the short head from the coracoid process of the scapula. With its insertion on the tuberosity of the radius, the biceps brachii is the main forelimb flexor.
Now turn the specimen dorsal side up, and examine the superficial muscles of the hindlimb, using Figure 8a and 8b as a reference.

pageData.desc: Ventral view of the superficial musculature of the hindlimb, with labels
pageData.altText: Figure 8a: Ventral view of the superficial musculature of the hindlimb, with labels

pageData.desc: Dorsal view of the superficial musculature of the hindlimb, with labels
pageData.altText: Figure 8b: Dorsal view of the superficial musculature of the hindlimb, with labels

pageData.text: As you examine the superficial muscles of the lateral thigh, look for the large gluteus superficialis. It originates, via a broad sheet of fascia, from both the ilium and the sacrum, and inserts near the greater trochanter of the femur. The gluteus superficialis is a thigh abductor. It also serves to flex and extend the thigh.

The tensor fascia latae is a thin, fanshaped muscle that originates on both the ilium and from nearby fascia. Its insertion is the fascia lata, the connective tissue sheath that overlies the gluteus medius and vastus lateralis muscles of the thigh (examined in Figure 8b). Contraction of the tensor fascia latae extends the hindlimb.

The biceps femoris lies caudal to the gluteus superficialis. It runs from an origin on the ischial tuberosity to an insertion on the dorsal aspect of the tibia and the patella (kneecap). The biceps femoris is a thigh abductor and hindlimb flexor.

The semitendinosus is visible just adjacent to the base of the tail. This hindlimb flexor originates from the sacrum and the caudal vertebrae, and inserts on the tibia. This muscle is very slender, with a long tendon at its insertion.

Turn the specimen ventral side up to examine the medial superficial hindlimb musculature. Examine the cranial region of the proximal portion of the hindlimb for the large muscle group known as the quadriceps femoris. These muscles serve as the main extensor of the hindlimb. The rectus femoris is a hindlimb extensor that originates on the ilium and inserts on the crest of the tibia. The vastus medialis originates on the diaphysis of the femur and inserts on the patella and the head of the tibia. (In Activity 2, you will examine the deeper members of the quadriceps femoris, the vastus lateralis and vastus intermedius.)
Medial to the rectus femoris, locate the small pectineus. This hip flexor and thigh adductor originates from the cranial region of the pubis and inserts on the proximal diaphysis of the femur.

The adductor magnus and adductor brevis are a parallel pair of thigh adductors located caudal to the vastus medialis that both insert on the femur. The adductor magnus originates on the ischium, and the adductor brevis on the pubis.

The gracilis is a pair of superficial thigh adductors named for their positions relative to one another. The gracilis cranialis has its origin on the pubis, and the gracilis caudalis on the ischium; both insert on the proximal aspect of the tibia.

The semimembranosus is easiest to locate just caudal to the gracilis caudalis. It is a long, thin, hindlimb extensor with its origin on the ischium and insertion on the medial portion of the tibia. Due to its thinness, this muscle is easily overlooked. It is somewhat broader than the nearby semitendinosus.
Note: Before proceeding to Activity 2, make sure you have identified and photographed all of the muscles from Activity 1.

In Activity 2, you will examine the <button class='glossary-text'>deep</button> musculature of the specimen. You will examine the head, neck and torso regions, then the forelimbs and hindlimbs. You will work primarily on the left side of the specimen, leaving the <button class='glossary-text'>superficial</button> muscles on the right side intact as much as possible for review.

typeBefore.text: Take photos of all the muscles listed in this activity, which appear in bold throughout the procedure. You may group multiple muscles into the same photograph. It is best to take photos before cutting through any muscles, because in some cases you will identify a muscle and then bisect or remove it in order to access an even deeper structure. Your kit includes T-pins, which may be used to secure the legs of the specimen while examining the musculature, or to indicate muscles of interest in your photographs. For best practices in specimen photography, review the video .
Please follow any additional directions provided by your instructor pertaining to the photography and/or identification of specific structures.

pageData.text: In this activity, you will examine the deeper musculature of the rat. As in the previous activity, use your blunt probe to gently coax adjacent muscles apart from one another. When you are instructed to cut through specific muscles, use the scissors, not the scalpel. You will work primarily on the left side of the specimen, leaving the muscles of the right side intact as much as possible for review.

Note: Remember that the terms “left” and “right” in anatomical terminology refer to the right and left sides of the specimen, not the experimenter, when the specimen is side down, side up, as shown in .
Turn the specimen dorsal side up, and begin your examination of the musculature of the head, neck, and torso, using Figure 9 as a reference.

pageData.desc: Dorsal and lateral view of the deeper musculature of the neck, and torso, and forelimb, with labels
pageData.altText: Figure 9: Dorsal and lateral view of the deeper musculature of the neck, and torso, and forelimb, with labels

pageData.text: Locate the cervical and thoracic trapezius and latissimus dorsi from Activity 1. Lifting up with the scissors, bisect (cut through the center) of each muscle and reflect it (push it back to either side of the incision). One of the muscles revealed will be the strap-like rhomboideus capitis, with its distinctive, stretched rhomboidal shape. It has its on the first four thoracic vertebrae (T1-T4), and inserts on the ventral aspect of the scapula. The contraction of the rhomboideus capitis adducts the scapula and pulls it cranially.

Turn the specimen ventral side up to examine the ventral neck and shoulder musculature. Use Figure 10 as a guide. Bisect and reflect the digastric and sternohyoid muscles, which you identified in Activity 1. Carefully bisect only the more superficial portion of the sternomastoid, and reflect it to reveal the deep portion of this muscle.

pageData.desc: Superficial and deep musculature of the pectoral and abdominal regions, with labels
pageData.altText: Figure 10: Superficial and deep musculature of the pectoral and abdominal regions, with labels

pageData.text: Now turn the specimen ventral side up, and direct your attention to the pectoral region. Locate the pectoralis superficialis and pectoralis profundus from Activity 1. Bisect and reflect both muscles to reveal the rectus abdominis as shown in Figure 10. This long, flat compressor of the abdomen originates on the pubis and inserts on the first two costal cartilages and the sternum.

Now direct your attention more caudally, to the lower abdominal region of the ventral surface. Locate the external oblique from Activity 1. Using your forceps, carefully lift a small amount of external oblique and cut through it with the scissors. Underneath, you should see the internal abdominal oblique (Figure 11) with running perpendicular to those of the external oblique muscle. The internal oblique arises from the lumbodorsal fascia, the crest of the ilium, and the inguinal ligament (a band of connective tissue which runs between the pubic tubercle and the iliac spine). It inserts at the linea alba, and, like the external oblique, compresses the abdomen and flexes the trunk.

pageData.desc: Superficial and deep muscles of the abdomen, with labels
pageData.altText: Figure 11: Superficial and deep muscles of the abdomen, with labels

pageData.text: Turn the specimen dorsal side up, and begin your examination of the deeper forelimb and shoulder muscles, using as a guide.

Locate the supraspinatus, which lies to the rhomboideus capitis; in fact, its most dorsal end runs underneath. This shoulder originates on the scapula just to its spine, and inserts on the greater tubercle on the portion of the humerus.
The more caudally located teres major is small compared to the rhomboideus capitis and supraspinatus. It acts as a shoulder and forelimb adductor, with an origin on the scapula and on the humerus.

The infraspinatus originates on the side of the scapular spine (recall that the supraspinatus originates on the cranial side), and inserts on the greater tubercle of the humerus. It serves to both adduct and rotate the forelimb.

Locate the triceps brachii along the caudal side of the proximal forelimb, covering most of the humerus. In order to fully view this muscle, you may need to bisect and reflect the tensor fasciae antebrachii, a very thin superficial muscle that covers the portion of the triceps. (The tensor fasciae antebrachii often comes away with the skin, so it may not be present on your skinned specimen.) You may also need to rotate the forelimb and/or the entire specimen to get the best view of the triceps. The long head of the triceps originates on the scapula, while its lateral head originates on the lateral aspect of the humerus. (There is also a small medium head visible from the medial aspect of the arm.) The insertion of the triceps is on the olecranon process of the ulna. The triceps is the major extensor of the forelimb.

Flip the specimen dorsal side up, and turn your attention to the hindlimb. Locate the gluteus superficialis, biceps femoris, semitendinosus, and tensor fasciae latae from Activity 1. Bisect and reflect these muscles, and identify the deeper hindlimb musculature, using Figure 12 as a guide. Beneath the gluteus superficialis you will see the gluteus medius. This thigh abductor originates on the lateral aspect of the ilium and inserts on the greater trochanter of the femur.

pageData.desc: Deep musculature of the hindlimb, with labels
pageData.altText: Figure 12: Deep musculature of the hindlimb, with labels

pageData.text: The vastus lateralis is located to the gluteus medius, on the cranial portion of the proximal hindlimb. It is a large hindlimb extensor, with an origin on the greater trochanter of the femur and an insertion on the vastus medialis and rectus femoris muscles.
The piriformis lies caudal to the gluteus medius. Its origin is on the ilium, and its insertion is on the greater trochanter of the femur. It serves to abduct the thigh.
The adductor magnus is caudal to the vastus lateralis. As the name indicates, this is a thigh adductor. Its origin is on the ischium, and its insertion is on the proximal diaphysis of the femur.

Working more distally on the hindlimb, bisect and reflect the semimembranosus, gracilis, and biceps femoris. This will reveal the large gastrocnemius, a powerful extensor of the hind foot. (You will need to rotate the hindlimb slightly to best view the entire gastrocnemius as well as the following muscles.) The gastrocnemius has two origins: both the lateral head and medial head arise from the lateral epicondyle of the femur. The two heads converge and share a common insertion on the calcaneus. Also inserted on the calcaneus is a smaller hind foot extensor, the soleus, which arises from the head of the fibula and lies to the gastrocnemius. The soleus and gastrocnemius are collectively known as the triceps surae. Using the blunt probe, separate the soleus from the gastrocnemius so that it is clearly visible.

Continue using the blunt probe to separate the soleus from the deeper and more lateral extensor digitorum longus. This long, thin muscle arises from the lateral epicondyle of the femur and inserts at the bases of the distal phalanges. As the name suggests, this muscle is an extensor of the toes.

Looking more medially and adjacent to the medial head of the gastrocnemius, locate the tibialis caudalis. Arising from the proximal regions of the tibia and fibula and inserting on the metatarsals, the tibialis caudalis serves as a hind foot extensor. The tibialis cranialis, best seen from a somewhat more lateral view, originates from the lateral diaphysis of the tibia and inserts on metatarsal I; it opposes the of the tibialis caudalis, acting as a hind foot flexor.

pageData.desc: Deep musculature of the distal hindlimb, with labels
pageData.altText: Figure 13: Deep musculature of the distal hindlimb, with labels

pageData.text: Dispose of any leftover Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> fluid down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the solution.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: Rinse and carefully air-dry the dissection tools and return the materials to your dissection set.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
When you are finished working with your specimen, place it in its resealable bag, and put the bag into an opaque trash bag for disposal in the household garbage.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
Sanitize the work space with 70% alcohol or other non-bleach disinfectant.

You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

text: What is an antagonistic muscle pair? What is the role of each member of the pair?
What is a synergist?
Which deep abdominal muscle would be particularly important for a rat in forced exhalation, forced defecation, and giving birth? Describe how the name of this muscle is derived.
List the members of the quadriceps femoris muscle group. How does the name of this muscle group reflect its anatomy?

pageData.content: Investigation Overview
Figure 1. The origins, insertions, and skeletal muscles of the upper arm
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Origins and insertions of the biceps and triceps muscles of the human upper arm

pageData.content: Figure 2. The anatomical planes of a quadruped and a biped
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Illustration showing where the midsagittal, frontal, and transverse planes divide a quadruped (cat) and a biped (human)

pageData.title: Table 1.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>Common Anatomical Terms
pageData.content: Table 1. Common Anatomical Terms

tableData.text: Toward the head end of the biped body, or the upper part of a structure; above
Away from the head end of the biped body, or toward the lower part of a structure; below
Toward the front of the body; synonymous with cranial; synonymous with ventral in describing the biped body other than the head
Toward the back of the body; synonymous with caudal; synonymous with dorsal in describing the biped body other than the head
Away from the midline of the body; to the side
Near or toward the point of reference
Away from the point of reference, which is usually the attachment point
Toward the back of the body; synonymous with superior in quadrupeds, or in bipeds when referring to the head; synonymous with posterior in describing the biped body other than the head
Toward the belly or abdomen of the body; synonymous with inferior in quadrupeds, or in bipeds when referring to the head; synonymous with anterior in describing the biped body other than the head
Toward the head; synonymous with superior in bipeds
Toward the tail; synonymous with inferior in bipeds
Toward or along the surface of the body or a structure; external
Below the surface of the body or a structure; internal
Divides the body into equal left and right halves; often referred to as the midline or median plane
Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross sections
Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

pageData.title: Table 2.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>Common Muscle Actions Around Movable Joints
pageData.content: Table 2. Common Muscle Actions Around Movable Joints

tableData.text: Movement of two adjacent parts toward one another, decreasing the angle between the proximal and distal parts
Movement of two adjacent parts away from one another, increasing the angle between the proximal and distal parts
Movement of a body part away from the midline (of the body as a whole or a specific region of the body)
Movement of a body part toward the midline (of the body as a whole or a specific region of the body, such as a limb)
Movement of a body part around its own axis
Inward rotation of the forearm and palm, or sole of foot
Outward rotation of the forearm and palm, or sole of foot
Movement in superior (upper) direction; for example, bringing the lower jaw (mandible) toward the upper (maxilla)
Movement in an inferior (downward) direction; for example, movement of the lower jaw (mandible) away from the upper (maxilla)

pageData.title: Table 3.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak> Naming Skeletal Muscles
pageData.content: Table 3. Naming Skeletal Muscles

tableData.text:
Temporalis—lies over the temporal bone of the cranium
Tibialis anterior—anterior to the tibia
Supra—above
Infra—below

Adductor—responsible for adduction at a joint
Extensor—responsible for extension at a joint
Rotator—responsible for rotation at a joint
Pronator—responsible for pronation at a joint
Sternomastoid—origin on sternum/insertion on mastoid process (of temporal bone)

Rectus—fibers run parallel to long axis of muscle
Transverse—fibers run perpendicular to long axis
Oblique—fibers run oblique (slantwise) to long axis

pageData.content: Experimental Design Diagram
pageData.altText:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation.  You will start by setting up the work area and your dissection tools. You will also remove the skin, fat and fascia from the specimen.

In Activity 1, you will need to locate and identify the superficial musculature of the head, neck and torso. Then locate and identify the superficial musculature of the forelimbs. Next, locate and identify the superficial musculature of the hindlimbs.

In Activity 2, you will need to locate and identify the deep musculature of the head, neck, and torso. Next locate and identify the deep musculature of the forelimbs. Then, locate and identify the deep musculature of the hindlimbs.

data.title: Abduction
data.content: Movement of a body part away from the midline

data.title: Action
data.content: The movement that results when the muscle contracts

data.title: Adduction
data.content: Movement of a body part toward the midline

data.title: Agonist
data.content: The principal muscle that drives an action (prime mover)

data.title: Antagonist
data.content: A muscle whose action counteracts that of another specified muscle

data.title: Antagonistic muscle pair
data.content: One muscle contracts the other muscle relaxes or lengthens

data.title: Anterior
data.content: Toward the front of the body; synonymous with cranial; synonymous with ventral in describing the biped body other than the head

data.title: Caudal
data.content: Toward the tail; synonymous with inferior in bipeds

data.title: Cranial
data.content: Toward the head; synonymous with superior in bipeds

data.title: Deep
data.content: Below the surface of the body or a structure; internal

data.title: Depression
data.content: Movement in an inferior (downward) direction. For example,  movement of the lower jaw (mandible) away from the upper (maxilla)

data.title: Distal
data.content: Farther from the body’s midline or center

data.title: Distal
data.content: Away from the point of reference, which is usually the attachment point

data.title: Dorsal
data.content: Toward the back of the body; synonymous with superior in quadrupeds, or in bipeds when referring to the head; synonymous with posterior in describing the biped body other than the head

data.title: Elevation
data.content: Movement in superior (upper) direction. For example,  bringing the lower jaw (mandible) toward the upper (maxilla)

data.title: Extension
data.content: Movement of two adjacent parts away from one another, increasing the angle between the proximal and distal parts

data.title: Extensor
data.content: A muscle whose contraction extends or straightens a limb or other part of the body

data.title: Fiber
data.content: Muscle cells have a long and slender shape

data.title: Flexion
data.content: Movement of two adjacent parts toward one another, decreasing the angle between the proximal and distal parts

data.title: Flexor
data.content: A muscule that decrease the angle between bones on two sides of a joint

data.title: Frontal plane
data.content: Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

data.title: Inferior
data.content: Away from the head end of the biped body, or toward the lower part of a structure; below

data.title: Insertion
data.content: The bone or other point of attachment (such as a tendon or other connective tissue) that tends to move the greatest distance when the muscle contracts

data.title: Lateral
data.content: Away from the midline of the body; to the side

data.title: Medial
data.content: Toward the midline

data.title: Midsagittal plane
data.content: Divides the body into equal left and right halves; often referred to as the midline or median plane

data.title: Origin
data.content: The bone that the muscle is attached to that has the greater mass and stability during contraction

data.title: Posterior
data.content: Toward the back of the body; synonymous with caudal; synonymous with dorsal in describing the biped body other than the head

data.title: Prime mover
data.content: The principal muscle that drives an action (agonist)

data.title: Pronation
data.content: Inward rotation of the forearm and palm, or sole of foot

data.title: Proximal
data.content: Near or toward the point of reference

data.title: Rostral
data.content: Toward the nose or mouth

data.title: Rotation
data.content: Movement of a body part around its own axis

data.title: Standard anatomical position
data.content: The pose in which a person is standing upright with their face forward, their arms at their sides, and their palms open

data.title: Superficial
data.content: Toward or along the surface of the body or a structure; external

data.title: Superior
data.content: Toward the head end of the biped body, or the upper part of a structure; above

data.title: Supination
data.content: Outward rotation of the forearm and palm, or sole of foot

data.title: Synergists
data.content: Muscles that work together and facilitate movements brought about by agonists at movable joints

data.title: Transverse plane
data.content: Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross sections

data.title: Ventral
data.content: Toward the belly or abdomen of the body; synonymous with inferior in quad-rupeds, or in bipeds when referring to the head
